{{multiple issues| {{context|date=January 2010}} {{more footnotes|date=January 2010}} }} {{Main|Zuni language}} This article discusses the '''[[phonology]] of the [[Zuni language]]''', spoken in the southwestern United States. ==Consonants== The 16 consonants of Zuni: {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" |- style="font-size: 90%;" ! colspan="2" rowspan="2" | ! rowspan="2" | [[Bilabial consonant|Bila
-bial]] ! colspan="2" | [[Dental consonant|Dental]]/
[[Alveolar consonant|Alveolar]] ! rowspan="2" | [[Postalveolar consonant|Post
-al.]] ! rowspan="2" | [[Palatal consonant|Pala
-tal]] ! colspan="2" | [[Velar consonant|Velar]] ! rowspan="2" | [[Glottal consonant|Glo-
ttal]] |- style="font-size: 80%;" ! [[Central consonant|cen.]] ! [[Lateral consonant|late.]] ! plain ! [[Labialisation|labi.]] |- ! colspan="2" | [[Nasal consonant|Nasal]] | {{IPAlink|m}} | {{IPAlink|n}} | | | | | | |- ! rowspan="2" | [[Stop consonant|Stop]] ! plain | {{IPAlink|p}} | {{IPAlink|t}} | | | ({{IPA|kʲ}}) | {{IPAlink|k}} | {{IPA|kʷ}} | {{IPAlink|ʔ}} |- ! [[Ejective consonant|ejective]] | | | | | | ({{IPAlink|kʼ}}) | ({{IPA|kʼʷ}}) | |- ! rowspan="2" | [[Affricate consonant|Affricate]] ! plain | | {{IPAlink|ts}} | | {{IPAlink|tʃ}} | | | | |- ! [[Ejective consonant|ejective]] | | ({{IPAlink|tsʼ}}) | | ({{IPAlink|tʃʼ}}) | | | | |- ! colspan="2" | [[Fricative consonant|Fricative]] | | {{IPAlink|s}} | {{IPAlink|ɬ}} | {{IPAlink|ʃ}} | | | | {{IPAlink|h}} |- ! colspan="2" | [[Approximant consonant|Approximant]] | | | {{IPAlink|l}} | | {{IPAlink|j}} | | {{IPAlink|w}} | |} *{{IPA|/t/}} is dental; {{IPA|/ts, s, n/}} are alveolar; {{IPA|/l/}} is [[Apical consonant|apical]]. *{{IPA|/ts, tʃ, k, kʷ/}} are phonetically [[Aspiration (phonetics)|aspirated]], {{IPA|[tsʰ, tʃʰ, kʰ, kʷʰ]}}, while {{IPA|/p, t, ʔ/}} are unaspirated. *A sequence of a stop or affricate and a glottal stop {{IPA|/ʔ/}} is phonetically realized as an [[ejective]]. This pronunciation occurs within words and across word boundaries: {{IPA|/ʔaːtʃ ʔuluka/}} ('they two put it in') as {{IPA|[ʔaːtʃʼulucʰæ]}}. Some analyses have proposed that the sequences {{IPA|/tsʔ, tʃʔ, kʔ, kʷʔ/}} be considered single ejective consonant phonemes {{IPA|/tsʼ, tʃʼ, kʼ, kʼʷ/}} based on their [[phonotactic]] properties.See {{Harvcoltxt|Davis|1966}}, {{Harvcoltxt|Newman|1965}}, {{Harvcoltxt|Newman|1967}}, {{Harvcoltxt|Walker|1966}}, {{Harvcoltxt|Walker|1972}}. *{{IPA|/k/}} and {{IPA|/kʷ/}} contrast only before {{IPA|/i, e, a/}}; before {{IPA|/u, o/}} the contrast is [[Phoneme#Neutralization, archiphoneme, underspecification|neutralized]] to {{IPA|/k/}}. This neutralization of contrast also applies to the sequences {{IPA|/kʔ, kʷʔ/}}. *{{IPA|/k, kʷ/}} are [[palatal]] {{IPA|[c, cʷ]}} before the vowels {{IPA|/i, e, a/}}, but are velar elsewhere. Since {{IPA|/k/}} is realized as an ejective before a [[glottal stop]], the sequences {{IPA|/kʔi, kʔe, kʔa/}} are phonetically {{IPA|[cʼi, cʼɛ, cʼæ]}}. *In a sequence of a stop or affricate plus another consonant (except {{IPA|/ʔ/}}), the stop/affricate has [[no audible release]]. That is, {{IPA|/moktʃinne/}} ('elbow') is phonetically {{IPA|[mɔk̚tʃʰinːɛ]}} and not {{IPA|[mɔkʰtʃʰinːɛ]}}. *All Zuni consonants occur with contrastive [[Length (phonetics)|duration]]: short or long. In Newman's analysis, the phonetically long consonants are [[geminate]]s (that is, a sequence of two identical consonants). {{Harvcoltxt|Walker|1972}} and {{Harvcoltxt|Granberry|1967}} analyze length {{IPA|/ː/}} as a separate [[phoneme]]. Geminate affricates are realized with a long closure period and a fricative release, e.g. {{IPA|/tsts/}} as {{IPA|[tːs]}}, {{IPA|/tʃtʃ/}} as {{IPA|[tːʃ]}}. *{{IPA|/h/}} is phonetically a voiceless vowel {{IPA|[h]}}, except when following a consonant in which case it is a velar fricative {{IPA|[x]}}: {{IPA|/ʔahha/}} ('pick it up!') is phonetically {{IPA|[ʔahxa]}}. *The [[sonorant]]s {{IPA|/m, n, l, w, j/}} (as well as vowels, see below) are optionally [[Consonant voicing and devoicing|devoiced]] when followed by {{IPA|/h, ʔ/}}. The devoicing occurs within words and across word boundaries. This is especially common when also preceded by a voiceless consonant (in addition to the following {{IPA|/h, ʔ/}}): {{IPA|/lesn hol/}} ('thus perhaps') pronounced {{IPA|[lɛsn̥hɔl]}}. *{{IPA|/n/}} is optionally realized as a phonetic velar {{IPA|[ŋ]}} before {{IPA|/k, kʷ/}}. *There is a marginal contrast between palatal {{IPA|[c]}} and velar {{IPA|[k]}} before the low vowel {{IPA|/a/}}. The usual pronunciation of {{IPA|/k/}} before {{IPA|/a/}} is palatal {{IPA|[c]}}. However, in some words — all of which are probably [[loanword]]s — a velar {{IPA|[k]}} occurs before {{IPA|/a/}} (notably in the very common word, {{IPA|/melika/}} ('non-Mormon Anglo-American'), which is phonetically {{IPA|[mɛlikʰa]}} and not {{IPA|[mɛlicʰæ]}}). This has led to an analysis of Zuni having two [[Dorsal consonant|dorsal]] phonemes, {{IPA|/kʲ/}} and {{IPA|/k/}}, by some linguists. A discussion of the disagreement between analyses and range of social variation of certain forms are discussed in {{Harvcoltxt|Tedlock|1969}}.The other articles are {{Harvcoltxt|Davis|1966}}, {{Harvcoltxt|Newman|1967}}, {{Harvcoltxt|Michaels|1971}}, {{Harvcoltxt|Walker|1966}}, {{Harvcoltxt|Walker|1972}}. ==Vowels== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" ! ! [[Front vowel|Front]] ! [[Back vowel|back]] |- ! [[Close vowel|High]] | {{IPA|i}} {{IPA|iː}} | {{IPA|u}} {{IPA|uː}} |- ! [[Open-mid vowel|Mid]] | {{IPA|e}} {{IPA|eː}} | {{IPA|o}} {{IPA|oː}} |- ! [[Open vowel|Low]] | colspan="2" | {{IPA|a}} {{IPA|aː}} |} * High {{IPA|/i, u/}} are typically {{IPA|[i, u]}}, but lowered variants {{IPA|[ɪ, ʊ]}} may be heard in unstressed syllables. * Mid {{IPA|/e, o/}} are typically {{IPA|[ɛ, ɔ]}}, but in unstressed syllables raised variants occur before [[Semivowel|glides]] with matching [[Vowel backness|backness]]: {{IPA|[e]}} before {{IPA|/j/}}, {{IPA|[o]}} before {{IPA|/w/}}. * Low central {{IPA|/a/}}, unlike the other vowels, is not reported to have [[allophonic]] variation by Newman. However, {{Harvcoltxt|Walker|1972}} reports its realization as fronted {{IPA|[æ]}} when it follows {{IPA|/k/}} (phonetically: {{IPA|[c]}}). * All vowels occur with contrastive [[Length (phonetics)|duration]]: short or long. In Newman's analysis, the phonetically long vowels are analyzed as distinct phonemes. {{Harvcoltxt|Walker|1972}} analyzes length {{IPA|/ː/}} as a separate [[phoneme]]. * Long {{IPA|/eː, oː/}} are typically {{IPA|[ɛː, ɔː]}}, but close variants {{IPA|[eː, oː]}} can occur in fast speech. * The other long vowels do not have variants with differing vowel quality. * Short vowels are optionally voiceless {{IPA|[i̥, ɛ̥, ḁ, ɔ̥, u̥]}} when at the end of an [[utterance]], e.g. the word {{IPA|/ʔaɬka/}} in {{IPA|/ʔitʃunan si ʔaɬka/}} ('after lying down then he slept') may be pronounced either {{IPA|[ʔaɬcʰæ̥]}} or {{IPA|[ʔaɬcʰæ]}}. Additionally, a short vowel or a sequence of a short vowel and glottal stop that occurs at the end of a word with more than one syllable is deleted when followed by a word that starts with {{IPA|/h, ʔ/}} (see also the devoicing of sonorant consonants above), e.g. {{IPA|/ʔaːtʃi hinina/}} ('they two are the same') as {{IPA|[ʔaːtʃhinina]}} (cf. {{IPA|/ʔaːtʃi jeːlahka/}} 'the two of them ran' where the final {{IPA|/i/}} of {{IPA|/ʔaːtʃi/}} is not deleted), and {{IPA|/ʔasselaʔ ʔelaje/}} ('they two are the same') as {{IPA|[ʔasːɛlʔɛlajɛ]}} (cf. {{IPA|/ʔasselaʔ powaje/}} 'the two of them ran' where the final {{IPA|/aʔ/}} of {{IPA|/ʔasselaʔ/}} is not deleted). ==Syllable and phonotactics== Zuni [[syllable]]s have the following specification: : C1(C2)V(ː)(C3)(C4) That is, all syllables must start with a consonant in the [[syllable onset]]. The onset may optionally have two consonants. The [[syllable coda]] is optional and may consist of a single consonant or two consonants. There are restrictions on the combinations with long vowels, which are listed below. ''Onset''. When the onset is a single consonant (i.e., CV(ː), CV(ː)C, or CV(ː)CC), C1 may be any consonant. When the onset is a two consonant cluster (i.e., CCV(ː), CCV(ː)C, or CCV(ː)CC), C1 may only be {{IPA|/ts, tʃ, k, kʷ/}}, and C2 may only be {{IPA|/ʔ/}}. These onset clusters can occur word-initially. ''Nucleus''. Any vowel of either length may be the [[syllable nucleus]] when open (i.e., has no coda: CV(ː) or CCV(ː)) or with a single consonant coda (i.e., CV(ː)C or CCV(ː)C). When the coda consists of two consonant cluster, the nucleus may be any short vowel; however, long vowels only occur with coda consisting of {{IPA|/tsʔ, tʃʔ, kʔ, kʷʔ/}}.{{Harvcoltxt|Newman|1965}} reports only {{IPA|/kʔ/}} after long vowels, but further fieldwork by {{Harvcoltxt|Walker|1966}} also finds {{IPA|/tsʔ, tʃʔ, kʷʔ/}}. ''Coda''. A single coda C3 may be any consonant. When the coda is a two consonant cluster (i.e., CV(ː)CC or CCV(ː)CC), any combination of consonants may occur with the following exception: if C3 is {{IPA|/ts, tʃ, kʷ/}}, then C4 can only be either {{IPA|/ʔ/}} or an identical consonant (C3 = C4). ''Non-[[tautosyllabic]] combinations''. Inside words, a short vowel plus a two consonant coda (i.e., CVCC or CCVCC) may only be followed by a syllable with a {{IPA|/ʔ/}} onset. Likewise, a long vowel plus a single consonant coda (i.e., CVːC or CCVːC) may only be followed by a {{IPA|/ʔ/}} onset. An open syllable (i.e., CV(ː) or CCV(ː)) and a short vowel plus a single consonant coda (i.e., CVC or CCVC) may be followed by a syllable with any possible onset. ==Prosody== {{Expand section|date=June 2008}} At the word level, the first syllable of lexical words receive [[Stress (linguistics)|stress]]. Although the [[Acoustic phonetics|acoustic]] correlates of stress are not fully described in Newman's grammar, at least vowel length is a significant correlate: short vowels are lengthened under syllable-initial stress. Stressed long vowels do not appear to have perceptible variation in duration. Stress at the phrase level was not fully studied by Newman, and, therefore, its details are not well known. Pronouns and certain particles consisting of a single syllable are unstressed when inside clauses, but are stressed at the beginning of phrases. ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==References== * {{citation |last=Davis |first=Irvine |year=1966 |title=Review of ''Zuni grammar'' by Stanley Newman] |journal=International Journal of American Linguistics |volume=32 |pages=82–84 |doi=10.1086/464883 }} *{{citation |last=Michaels |first=David |year=1971 |title=A note on some exceptions in Zuni phonology |journal=International Journal of American Linguistics |volume=37 |pages=189–191 |doi=10.1086/465159 }} *{{citation |last=Newman |first=Stanley |year=1965 |title=Zuni grammar |series=University of New Mexico publications in anthropology |volume=14 |place=Albuquerque |publisher=University of New Mexico }} *{{citation |last=Newman |first=Stanley |year=1967 |title=Zuni grammar: Alternative solutions versus weaknesses |journal=International Journal of American Linguistics |volume=33 |pages=187–192 |doi=10.1086/464959 }} * {{citation |last=Tedlock |first=Dennis |year=1969 |title=The problem of k in Zuni phonemics |journal=International Journal of American Linguistics |volume=35 |pages=67–71 |doi=10.1086/465044}} *{{citation |last=Walker |first=Willard |year=1966 |title=[Review of ''Zuni grammar'' by Stanley Newman] |journal=Language |volume=42 |issue=1 |pages=176–180 |doi=10.2307/411614 }} *{{citation |last=Walker |first=Willard |year=1966 |title=Inflection and taxonomic structure in Zuni |journal=International Journal of American Linguistics |volume=32 |issue=3 |pages=217–227 |doi=10.1086/464906 }} *{{citation |last=Walker |first=Willard |year=1972 |title=Toward a sound pattern of the Zuni |journal=International Journal of American Linguistics |volume=38 |issue=4 |pages=240–259 |doi=10.1086/465223 }} ==Further reading== *Bunzel, Ruth L.
